Based on the information below (copied from bug 6373), it appears that the 
scenario was

1. Create a Java project
2. Set the sharing
3. Perform a Replace With/Stream Contents

The method that we normally suggest is

1. Create a Java project
2. Peform an Add to Workspace from the Repository browser

Could you try this out and see if this works for you.

Copied from bug 6373
> I created a Java Project and set the Properties->Team. Then when I Replace
> With->Stream Contents it only gets 1026 of the 2473 files. Nothing in the
> log. In order to get it to complete I have to shutdown Eclipse and remove
> .metadata/.plugins/org.eclipse.core.resources/.projects/<project_name>/.sync
> info repeatedly. This also takes ~4 - 6 hours to check out. I'm using
> 20011107 on Windows 2000SP2 with the latest IBM 1.3 JDK.
> 
> The  second time I tried my 'trick' above I got the following log message
> Log: Tue Nov 27 14:15:58 MST 2001

The reason the Replace takes so much time is because we perform a sync before 
replacing the resources. Although this approach works well when there is a 
small number of differences between the repository and the local workspace, it 
has devestating effects for large projects with lots of changes (especially 
involving directories). The scenario in this bug represents the worst case 
scenario for the Repace with/Stream contents. 

Perhaps we should consider either reverting back to a straight Replace without 
a sync or providing an option to allow the user to select whether to do a sync 
on replace.

I was following James Moody's sugestion from the newsgroup. I will try your 
suggestion and report back.

I was able to check out the entire project. Although 
java.lang.NullPointerException was still thrown. And it only took 7 minutes. 
Which is almost as fast as command line cvs.

Thanks.
